text: 1. Then G âratkârava Ârtabhâga 2 asked. 'Yâ g ñ avalkya,' he said, 'how many Grahas are there, and how many Atigrahas 3 ?'

text: 'Eight Grahas,' he replied,' and eight Atigrahas.'

text: 10. 'Yâ g ñ avalkya,' he said, 'everything is the food of death. What then is the deity to whom death is food?'

text: 11. 'Yâ g ñ avalkya,' he said, 'when such a person (a sage) dies, do the vital breaths (prâ n as) move out of him or no?'

text: 'No,' replied Yâ g ñ avalkya; 'they are gathered up in him, he swells, he is inflated, and thus inflated the dead lies at rest.'

text: Yâ g ñ avalkya said: 'Take my hand, my friend. We two alone shall know of this; let this question of ours not be (discussed) in public.' Then these two went out and argued, and what they said was karman (work), what they praised was karman 1 , viz. that a man becomes good by good work, and bad by bad work. After that G âratkârava Ârtabhâga held his peace.
